Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: A Digital Design-Delivery System for the Large-scale Deployment of Mass Timber Building Technologies
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to democratize mass timber systems, rendering them accessible across the architecture, engineering, and construction (AEC) industry. Buildings account for 40% of all greenhouse gas emissions, indicating an urgent need for energy-intelligent building prototypes. Mass timber buildings require less energy for production than competitive technologies and were approved in 2019 by the International Building Code for structures of up to 18 stories in the US. Yet, they remain inaccessible as a technology, in part because developers, architects and manufacturers remain unfamiliar with mass timber and its benefits. This proposal seeks to unlock a latent market of development potential on sites to which mass timber offers unique advantages. Because our technology integrates adaptable-to-site building solutions into the industry's supply chain, it is designed to improve adoption by reducing risks, barriers, and costs usually associated with innovative technologies. By giving designers, engineers, and builders access to cutting-edge mass timber building systems, our proposal aims to encourage the use of a sustainable and profitable technology for the rapid urbanization of North American cities.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will focus on developing adaptable mass timber building solutions that are replicable and commercializable. This will be achieved by designing a variety of rigorously tested and cost-effective building solutions in mass timber and developing a generative design system that can generate and deploy optimal building proposals using these pre-designed building solutions. The first component of our technology comprises the development of pre-approved structural building solutions across a range of building scales (3-18 stories) and mass-timber technologies, including novel hybrid structural solutions developed with support from manufacturers and engineers. The second component the generative system will handle different development scenarios from large urban blocks to small urban infill sites. The tool will generate a wide variety of potential compliant options, analyze and test these for user-specified performance metrics, and sort among them to find a best-case building proposal. The tool will incorporate the structural solutions developed in the first component of the work and deploy them within their constraints to test real-world building solutions against the constraints of each development project. The tool will also seamlessly integrate with existing BIM (Building Information Modeling) project-delivery platforms for easy interoperability.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Generate is a technology company aimed at both digitizing the construction industry and accelerating the use of sustainable building materials.

In Phase I, Generate began the development of Mastermodel: a first-of-its-kind, Computer-Aided Design for Manufacturing (CADfM) software. Mastermodel will enable architects to design in a code, cost, carbon and product-aware space that links design to manufacturing, short-circuiting the linear practice of project delivery. During Phase I, Generate focused exclusively on the first two phases of architectural design, where the implementation of design-for-manufacturing processes results in significant yields: namely, the Concept Design and Schematic Design phases.

Mastermodel is unique among design software in that it consists of two mutually reinforcing systems: its Building-Aware Design (BAD) system and its Standard Design Library (SDL).

The BAD system---a geometry kernel with smart building elements (facade, corridor, spaces, etc.) aware of their type, purpose and adjacencies---permits data communication between building assemblies. In BAD, architects can draw building shapes which automatically generate residential units and circulation, resulting in significant time savings. As BAD stores all relationships and parameters between elements, users can rapidly change design in it: e.g., from an all-1-bedroom to an all-2-bedroom layout, or from a hybrid timber-steel building to a fabrication-ready, full timber building in seconds.

The SDL---a multilevel database with manufacturers' products---enables design-for-manufacturing by permitting architects to fluidly test and integrate products into their early design concepts. With photorealistic graphics, the SDL offers manufacturers a digital showroom: a portal through which to integrate their products into architectural projects. The SDL provides parameterized, pre-engineered, and pre-vetted building systems, designed through a vast inventory of cost, carbon, code and product data.

In its forward state, Mastermodel will permit architects to test and fluidly integrate different products into their early designs. With photorealistic graphics, it will offer manufacturers a customizable, digital showroom: a portal through which to integrate their products into architects' projects.

Generate's conceptual Phase I research advanced alongside several applied research initiatives. In Phase I, Generate developed Mastermodel 0---a non-commercial version of its CADfM software---relying on datasets from numerous architectural projects.

Among these is Generate's Model C (devised in partnership with Boston design-build firm Placetailor), which will meet Passive House standards, and function as a CO2 sink by reducing embodied and operational emissions. The project was used to inaugurate Mastermodel's SDL---by hosting select mass timber products---and to carefully map out architects' "job to be done" in terms of inputs, decisions, actions and deliverables, all of which informs the BAD system.

The Tallhouse was another Phase I research effort that investigated six structural typologies on an eight-story residential building in Boston (concrete; steel; timber; and hybrids). Generate performed a full Life-Cycle Analysis showing the Global Warming Potential of each building type through its material acquisition, construction, maintenance, and demolition. This effort yielded exciting results from Life Cycle Assessment, which confirmed significant carbon emission reductions from use of mass timber and other hybrid methods (up to 73%).

Generate relied on its extensive customer discovery, with hundreds of potential end-users, to prioritize feature development. These include surface area-to-volume ratio, gross square footage, net rentable square footage, floor-area ratio, open space percentage, lineal feet of facade, unit mix, unit count, occupancy counts and ratios, window-to-wall ratio and mass timber material volume and cost.

Generate also made progress on the development of simple visualization tools that allow end-users to smoothly switch between different views with photorealistic sun lighting, shadows, and materials. Mastermodel now allows for dynamic light and shadow and three basic camera views: a 3D view with advanced camera manipulation tools; a 2D view with simple zoom and pan tools; and a 3D walkthrough view that gives users the immersive experience of walking through a game-like environment.

Mastermodel is designed to enable greater flexibility, lower cost, greater project speed, and wider product selection, serving as a portal of entry into mainstream architecture for mass timber, through its becoming a broadly used, easy to use, cost-effective, superior design tool.

Mastermodel's ease of use and information optimization will make obsolete the menial tasks of project delivery, while enhancing human creativity in design. As architects become able to design better, smarter and faster, the US will see a critical increase in biophilic and affordable housing. By tackling some of the most pressing challenges of our century, Mastermodel will address the urgent need to build more quickly, densely, sustainably and cost-effectively. In doing so, it will catalyze a new paradigm in CAD technologies.


Last Modified: 03/15/2021
Modified by: John Klein

By tackling some of the most pressing challenges of our century, Mastermodel will address the urgent need to build more quickly, densely, sustainably and cost-effectively.
